output.crosstab_text:
For first degree graduates of all subjects, five years after graduation, the industry with the highest proportion of female graduates is Human health and social work activities, and the median earnings of females in this industry were £29,200. The industry with the highest proportion of male graduates was Professional, scientific and technical activities and the median earnings of males in this industry were £34,700.

The biggest difference in proportions is seen in Human health and social work activities where the proportion of female graduates is 14.7 percentage points higher than the proportion of male graduates. The biggest difference in median earnings is seen in Mining and quarrying where the median earnings of male graduates were £16,600 higher than the median earnings of female graduates. The group with the highest earnings was Male graduates who worked in the Mining and quarrying industry (median earnings of £52,900). 43.7% of female graduates are concentrated in the top 2 industries (either Human health and social work activities or Education), whereas for male graduates this is 18.6%.
output.crosstab_title: Industry of graduate employment for graduates of all subjects by sex, five years after graduation, male and female first degree graduates from English HE providers, 2020/21 tax year.
